newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhs "disturbed" by unrest in nearby China.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhs "disturbed" by unrest in nearby China.

text.p: The head of Kazakhstan's Security Council said on Tuesday he was concerned about events across the border in China's turbulent northwest province of Xinjiang.

"We are disturbed by events in Xinjiang," Beksultan Sarsekov, secretary of the Security Council, told a news conference in the Kazakh capital Almaty. It was Kazakhstan's first official reaction to the Xinjiang troubles.

Last month, anti-Chinese riots in the town of Yining, located near the Chinese-Kazakh border, left nine dead and 198 wounded. This followed increasing tensions between ethnic Chinese and Xinjiang's Moslem, Turkic-speaking Uighur population.

On Monday, one of several Kazakhstan-based Uighur organisations fighting for an independent "East Turkestan" in Xinjiang said China had executed five Uighur rioters. Chinese officials denied the allegation.

"A certain part of the Chinese population is arguing for its sovereignty and would like to follow the Chechen scenario," Sarsekov said, in reference to Russia's bloody separatist conflict in Chechnya.
"They (Uighurs) are bringing some instability to the region," he said.
The ex-Soviet states neighbouring Xinjiang share the region's Turkic language, Islam and a nomadic past, and have fuelled Uighur dreams of independence.
However, the Central Asian states are sensitive to pressure from China, with whom they and Russia plan to sign a pact next month reducing troop levels along their common borders.

Some Uighur exiles believe that may make them unwelcome in Kazakhstan. "We will probably have to set up our headquarters in Istanbul or Germany," a Uighur leader told a congress of Uighur exile groups in Kazakhstan on Monday.
Sarsekov, while acknowledging the Uighur problem as China's internal affair, also gently criticised Beijing's tough crackdown on the Uighur unrest.
"The Chinese authorities are resorting to harsh measures," he said, adding: "We can as human beings feel and understand (the Uighurs)."
